description.narrative:
In Sierra Leone, an estimated 8 out of every 1,000 newborn babies die because they cannot breathe on their own (birth asphyxia). Only 54% of mothers in Sierra Leone give birth in health facilities—often because the cost is too high—which contributes to this statistic. Birth asphyxia is relatively easy to prevent, but prevention relies on the presence of a trained birth attendant that can resuscitate a newborn, if necessary.
World Hope International's (WHI) Helping Babies Breathe program is working to eliminate deaths due to birth asphyxia in five districts of Sierra Leone. This program trains birth attendants—both skilled (working in a health facility) and traditional (largely untrained)—in newborn resuscitation. Through this program, birth attendants are trained to perform infant resuscitation using a bag, a mask, and simple picture-based instructions. This intervention has the potential to eliminate newborn deaths due to birth asphyxia—and save more than 5,400 infant lives per year—in the targeted districts of Sierra Leone.
To track the impact of Helping Babies Breathe, WHI will track the number of birth attendants trained in newborn resuscitation throughout 2017, as well as the number of neonatal deaths (as compared to the baseline) in target districts. A milestone for program success will be the number of birth attendants trained in 2017; WHI’s goal is to train 2,150 birth attendants.

activity-date.narrative: Actual end date of the activity
Actual start date of the activity
